def: to chose not to take part in or consume
ex: Jamm abstained from the vote on the sale of the land after both his competitors helped him get out of Tammy 2's grasp.

def: not inclined towards physical exertion or effort, slow and relaxed
ex: Pam and Jim's languid fun run ended up being a win for everyone as they had bought a lamp that they handed to Michael as an award.

def: working in subtle/gradual destructive/sinister way
ex: Andy's insidious comments about Dwight were met with rejection from Michael. Michael loved Dwight no matter who hard Andy worked to change that.

def: characteristic of one eager to fight
ex: Everyone in the public hearing on building the park was belligerent towards Leslie , that she felt very angry and ended the meeting early.

def: incosistent, lacking in harmony or compatability or appropriateness
ex: Michael's image of the office as a family was probably incongruous with how others thought about it, espicially at the start when they could not wait to leave the office.

def: to plan or scheme
ex: April contrived of a plan to both fix animal control and not have to run it,. The plan was so good that the council immediately approved it.

def: (v) be a sign or indication of, have meaning
ex: Michael standing up on a podium and make a speech usually denotes that something really cringy is about to happen.

def: discontented as toward authority
ex: After knowing that Michael could get a bonus instead of the surplus, everyone became disaffected  and united on buying the chairs.

def: to make something bad better
ex: Pam tried to ameliorate Michael's existential pain at the bird funeral by make a speech that really resonated with Michael's anxieties. He seemed better after that.

def: firm and dependable in loyalty
ex: Leslie is a very staunch supporter of more government building of parks, whereas Ron is firmly against that.

def: to spread negative information about
ex: Sweetums and Councilman Jamm did their best to vilify Leslie as a terrible government bureuacrat to get her to lose the recall election.

def: to cleverly find a way out of obligations
ex: Michael circumvents doing any real work by pretending to be sick. Michael has  some kind of ache somewhere 40 times a year and Dwight takes it fairly seriously every time.

def: wasting resources recklessly (adj) or those who do that (n)
ex: Eagletonians are terrible profligates. They have a department of Infinity Pools that's so profilgate, Leslie closed it and put the department on hold.

def: to come from, be connected to, or to deduce by reason
ex: April's hate for Ann was derived from their competition over Andy as Ann had dated Andy for two years before April.

def: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as unworthy
ex: Andy's haughty attitude about studying at Cornell was quickly crushed by how incompetent he is as a salesman.

def: traveling from place to place to work
ex: Packer's itinerant job as a traveling salesman makes him an aannoying recurrent character that shows up to miss everything up and then leave it for the office to handle..

def: marked by or showing hopelessness
ex: Tommy seemed pretty forlorn about the fall of his empire, he could not image doing anything else. Yet, he found a way to bounce back as an author and all hope was restored.

def: marked by extreme intesity of emotions or convictions
ex: Michael was vehemently excited by Pam and Jim's engagement. He hugged Jim to the goround.

def: (adj) having only one meaning or interpretation, admitting of no doubt or misunderstanding
ex: Ron made his stance on government unequivocally clear to Leslie, tyet she could  not but misunderstand his very clear statements.

def: lasting a short time
ex: April's office friendships turned from ephemeral relationships to for-life friendshipss.

def: very prominent, standing above others in quality or position
ex: By the end of the show, either Ben or Leslie held the eminent position as POTUS. We don't know who, though I like to think it was Leslie.

def: being essentially equal to
ex: Jan's relationship with Michael is tantamount to Michael tying himself to a car thhat drives him off a cliff.

def: to assert
ex: Tom always maintained that he was going to become a rich successful businessman, even when it looked really bleak for him.

def: to reveal unintentionally
ex: When asked by Ron, Jerry quickly betrayed Leslie's plans to find a historical connection to the land.

def: an absurd presentation of something, a mockery
ex: The dysfunctional nature of the council Leslie was on was a travesty of how city councils truely work. Yet, there's probably some truth to it nevertheless, which made it even more humorous.

def: comprised of a variety of styles
ex: The final show on the stage was an eclectic mix of pop, rock, country, and even jazz.

def: immitative of another work
ex: Parks and Rec might have felt derivative from the Office at first, but then it quickly took on a life of its own that made great.

def: cannot be changed
ex: Ron's position on government was immutable from the start, it could not be changed no matter how hard Leslie worked to show him the importance of government in people's lives.

def: fanatical patriotism
ex: None of the shows I watch have any hit of jingoism. In fact, if itpatriotism comes up, it's usally in a sarcastic orsatirical way.

def: stubbornly unyielding
ex: Leslie was very tenacious about building the park on that pit, and she got it done despite all the challenges.

def: to put side by side for contrast
ex: At first, it might seem easy to juxtapose the Office and Parks and Rec. You have the fun crazy passionate boss, the terrible intern, the funny sidekick, tall and handsome white man... Yet Parks and Rec is really its own monster even if it starts out really derivative. They become hard to compare very quickly.

def: distinctive and showy elegence
ex: Tommy was able to turn his panache into profit with Rent-a-swag. He had enough nelegant showy clothes that kids really wanted.

def: plausable but false
ex: Tommy made a spurious claim that people call him the Indian Robert Dinero. It's plauable but definitely not true.

def: to clarify, make easier to understand
ex: Prison Mike tried to elucidate what life in prison is like. He only confused everyone when he said "dementors"

def: being in the early stages of development, being or invovling basic facts or principles
ex: Sherlock has a knack for uncovering seemingly complex mysteries as rather rudimentaryy trickstery.

def: tending to betray
ex: Dwight's treacherous meeting with Jan to take over Michael's position as manager was quickly forgiven by Michael , though not until he humiliated him enough.

def: hinder or prevent
ex: Michael felt frustrated with everyone for their apathy about his boss's death

def: noble and generous in spirit, espicially towards a rival or someone less in power
ex: Leslie's attempt at getting the Newports to be magnanimous by giving her the land for free did not work because Grizzle paid more than 125 million dollars for the land.

def: to make less angry, to placate (v)
ex: Ann and Ben always mollify Leslie with pancakes when giving her news she might not like

def: still in existence (in reference to documents)
ex: After 30 years, Leslie and Ben were suprised to find her River Cleanup document was still extant in Public Work circles as an example of great work.

def: to contain or include, to consider as part of a general rule or principle
ex: The Unity Festival subsumed all the great musicians of Indiana. It even included the Decemberists, and most importantly Duke Silver.

def: a long pompous speed or tirade (n), or to deliver such one (v)
ex: Leslie's harangue about Pawnee's lack of appreciation for her work was met with disapproval from the people of Pawnee and contributed to her loosing the election.

def: happy because of success
ex: Everyone was really jubilant for Leslie when Ben announced she's running for congress. They cheered and hugged her.

def: describe in detail
ex: Leslie handed April a binder that delineated her entire career over the next 10 years. It even included the exact month she would run for congress and win.

def: a person who holds unorthodox opinions in any field
ex: Michael was a heretic on management. He always treated the office as a family, whereas every other manager treated their offices as workspace and everyone under them as employees.

def: easily persuaded
ex: Ann is pretty amenable to Leslie's force of will and over-the-top complements, so Leslie can usually get her to do anything, like leaving nursing to take up a government job.

def: of a belief that is based on faulty reasoning
ex: Michael tried to  disprove any fallacious notion that there's anything wrong with being gay by kissing Oscar, which must have been really hard for him to do

def: free of deceit
ex: Erin is the most guileless character on the Office, which made her endearing that she did not try to trick Andy in any way, yet hard to digest that she could not handle herself as an adult.

def: lacking of emotion or enthusiasm
ex: Ben and Chris, who were used to general apathy towards government work in Indiana, were suprised by how much people cared in Pawnee and how many showed up to public meetings.

def: typical, found in the ordinary course of events
ex: Pretending to be Dwight is the quotidian prank that's typical of Jim's relationship to Dwight.

def: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
ex: Ron's refractory attitude towards government was surprising considering he held a public office and got paid with government money. He's always resistent to getting anything governmental work done or respecting the role of the government he worked for.

def: excessively greedy
ex: Bender's avaricious attitude masked a softer loving side under that selfish shell. He might steel a lot and want everything for himself, yet he still loved Fry a lot.

def: take the place of or move into the position of
ex: None of the managers brought in could really supplant Michael's role as manager. They had big shoes to fill.

def: so small they seem unimportant
ex: "I Braveheart" is an example of jokes that are negligible on the first watch, yet become more eminent as you watch the show a second and third time

def: (adj) being disrespectful; improperly forward or bold
ex: The tattoo shop owner's suggestion to build a disney park felt very impertinent to Leslie, especially since he was not invited, broke through a window to get in and it was a stupid unoriginal idea.

def: (adj) characterized by or characteristic of exceptionally early development or maturity (especially in mental aptitude)
ex: Even as a kid, Leslie was a precocious govenment worker. She even wrote down in her diary that she'd become a governor of Indiana.

def: practicing self-denial
ex: The Office's ascetic month trying to losing weight ended up being ineffective against the power of cake.
